Ethical Considerations

NaaS operates exclusively within the reconstructed temporal space. Your organic memories remain untouched by our proprietary NeuroLace™ framework. That said, users report that after extended sessions, the reconstructed memories can feel more vivid than the originals. This is not a bug — your brain simply prefers the higher-resolution version. We consider this a feature. Our legal team considers it a gray area. Dr. Stern considered it "deeply troubling" before she left.

We believe the right to your own past is inalienable. Terms apply.

The Mandela Effect Is a Design Flaw, Not a Conspiracy

Dr. Genevieve Stern, Ph.D, Cognitive Archaeology — Chief Science Officer
Published March 14, 2084 · 12 min read

Consider the Berenstain problem. Millions of adults insist the bears were spelled differently. They are not confused. They are not lying. They are remembering a past that was insufficiently archived. Human memory was never designed for the information density of the 21st century, let alone the 22nd. It buckled under the weight. We at NaaS do not "fix" memory — we provide a structurally sound alternative.

"We are not rewriting history. We are providing a draft."

The question is not whether reconstructed memories are "real." The question is whether your original memories were real either. Every neuroscientist since Bartlett has known that recall is reconstruction. You were already making it up. We just do it better, with proper lighting and a subscription model.

Where it gets complicated — and where Dr. Vance and I parted ways philosophically — is the question of consent. Not user consent. We have seventeen forms for that. I mean the consent of the memory itself. If a moment in time was experienced by someone who no longer exists in any measurable way, who owns the echo? NaaS says the subscriber. The courts say it depends. Eleanor said nobody does. Eleanor said memories are wild animals and we were building cages and charging admission and one day
